Welcome!

What is IGNITE?

The word â€œigniteâ€, according to the dictionary, means â€œto catch fire or cause to catch fire,â€ or â€œto arouse or inflame an emotion or situation.â€ Metaphorically, ignite signifies sparking passion, inspiration, or a surge of intense activity or emotion. It can describe awakening enthusiasm, lighting a fire within oneself, or triggering a powerful or transformative change.

Thatâ€™s how the idea for IGNITE? was conceived, and here it stands for Inspiring Girls through Networking, Innovation, and Technical Excellence.

IGNITE Itâ€™s a supportive, mid-term mentorship program designed to empower the next generation of women in science.

Who is Involved?

The heart of IGNITE is the founder and primary mentor, Dr. Emilyn Costa. She has thoughtfully invited accomplished women from her professional network â€“ experts in their respective scientific fields â€“ to generously share their valuable knowledge and real-world experiences.

Dr. Emilyn Costa is delighted to collaborate on the organizational aspects of the program with Miss Layana Rufino, a bright Masterâ€™s candidate and her mentee. Layana brings her excellent skills in scientific communication and outreach to the team.

We are incredibly grateful to all the inspiring women who contribute to IGNITE as volunteers, dedicating their precious time and expertise to this important initiative.

Who do We Support?

IGNITE is specifically created for girls and women pursuing careers in science, particularly those in their early stages of academic journeys, including Bachelorâ€™s, Honours, Masterâ€™s, Doctoral, and Post-doctoral levels.

Why Does IGNITE Matters?

Sparking Inspiration from a Drive for Change ğŸŒŸ

Dr. Emilyn Costa ConceiÃ§Ã£o Sharma ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ”¬ ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· earned her doctorate in Brazil during a period of significant political instability and underinvestment in science, immediately following the completion of her degree. Despite Brazilâ€™s full support for her education, a shift in government political party - click here to know more - led to instability and contributed to the subsequent diaspora of highly qualified individuals from the country.

Facing a lack of postdoctoral opportunities and no previous experience in industry, she found herself compelled to remove her academic titlesâ€”â€œDr.â€ and â€œMScâ€ (masters)â€”from her CV in order to apply for positions in the private sector. One such opportunity was a role in the administration of a health facility ğŸ¥, where the offered salary matched Brazilâ€™s minimum wageâ€”an amount attainable with only the high school certificate.

In an unexpected turn, while supporting a fellow PhD colleague in a similar situation, Dr. Emilyn Costa was invited to join a diagnostic bacteriology laboratory (Labbact) at INI/FIOCRUZ as a laboratory technologist (a role equivalent to that of a research assistant). This opportunity marked not only her return to scientific work but also the beginning of her first postdoctoral research internship. ğŸ”¬

Her hands-on experience in clinical research and TB diagnostics led to an offer to undertake a postdoctoral research project in Belgium ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡ª. At that time, she had to choose between continuing research in Europe ğŸŒ or coordinating laboratory activities for a clinical trial on TB genomics in South Africa ğŸ‡¿ğŸ‡¦â€”a topic that deeply aligned with her research interests. She chose South Africa, motivated by a commitment to addressing a disease that disproportionately affects countries of the Global South, such as Brazil and South Africa. The position promised not only scientific growth ğŸŒ± but also the chance to engage in meaningful knowledge exchange.

While in South Africa, she was encouraged to apply for independent research funding. However, this proved particularly difficult. The short-term nature of postdoctoral contracts, the lack of dedicated time for grant writing âœï¸, and her ineligibility due to nationality or residency criteria severely limited her access to funding opportunities. Officially a resident of Brazil and living temporarily in South Africa, she did not meet the criteria required by either countryâ€™s funding bodies. ğŸ˜”

Over time, she discovered that she fell into a professional gap. No longer considered an early-career researcher (due to exceeding the typical three-year post-PhD window), and without having led her own independent research as principal investigator (PI), she was also not recognized as mid-career. This left her in a â€œgravity-freeâ€ professional spaceâ€”without firm ground to establish herself and grow in the way she aspired. ğŸš€

Despite these obstacles, Dr. Costa ConceiÃ§Ã£o gained valuable skills throughout her international journey. From her doctoral studies in Europe, her diagnostic and clinical research work in Brazil, to her postdoctoral research in South Africa, she developed strong capabilities in self-management, scientific communication, quality control, strategic and critical thinking, mentorship, leadership, and time management. Most importantly, she came to understand the transformative power of scientific communities. ğŸ¤

A firm believer in the collective power of shared knowledge, Emilyn has turned her own experiences into a structured curriculum aimed at empowering girls and women. Her goal is to expand opportunities beyond those defined by formal education systems, enabling women to choose their professional paths rather than being passively chosenâ€”or excludedâ€”by systemic failures. Through mentorship, she hopes to reduce the number of women who abandon careers in STEM fields due to a lack of decent work opportunities. ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ«

The Crucial Role of Mentoring and Community for Women in STEM field ğŸŒŸ

Emilynâ€™s commitment to mentorship is also fueled by literature and research beyond her primary area of expertise. One article that recently inspired her is â€œWomen in STEM: The Importance of Mentorship and Communityâ€ by Prof. Michaela Gazdik Stofer, published by the American Society for Microbiology. The full text can be accessed clicking here. ğŸ˜‰

Prof. Stofer identifies several structural challenges commonly faced by women in STEM:

âœ”ï¸ Gender bias: Both conscious and unconscious biases that influence hiring, promotion, and recognition.

âœ”ï¸ Imposter syndrome: A persistent feeling among many women that they do not belong, despite their qualifications.

âœ”ï¸ Lack of representation: Fewer women in senior roles result in a scarcity of mentors and role models for early-career professionals.

âœ”ï¸ Work-life balance pressures: Disproportionate responsibilities outside of work often hinder womenâ€™s advancement in the field.

In response to these challenges, Prof. Michaela Stofer highlights mentorship and the formation of supportive communities as crucial mechanisms for progress. Emilynâ€™s own journey echoes this sentimentâ€”she continues to work toward building inclusive spaces where knowledge is shared, mentorship is prioritized, and the next generation of women in STEM can thrive.

IGNITE directly addresses these challenges by providing mentorship and fostering a supportive community.

When Does IGNITE Take Place?

The mentorship program runs for 12 months, from August to August.

Where Does IGNITE Operate?

While our organizational base is in South Africa and Brazil, the core of the program is delivered online, complemented by local in-person activities where possible.

How Does IGNITE Work?

The mentorship program is primarily conducted in English (Portuguese is welcome during meetings exclusively for Brazilian participants). Our curriculum focuses on developing both personal and professional skills, covering topics such as (but not limited to):

01 Personal Skills for Life

âœ”ï¸ Critical and creative thinking

âœ”ï¸ Effective communication: The art of speaking

âœ”ï¸ Self-presentation: Strategies for different contexts

âœ”ï¸ Personal budget and investment management

âœ”ï¸ Enhancing general reading comprehension

âœ”ï¸ Mental and physical woman Health

02 Professional Skills in Science

âœ”ï¸ Career exploration: Defining aspirations and pathways

âœ”ï¸ Conducting various types of literature reviews and studies

âœ”ï¸ Writing research proposals, abstracts, manuscripts, and potentially book chapters

âœ”ï¸ Designing impactful scientific posters and presentations

âœ”ï¸ Navigating the grant application process

âœ”ï¸ Organizing and managing research data

âœ”ï¸ Performing data analysis

âœ”ï¸ Effective time and task management

âœ”ï¸ Crafting strategic Curriculum Vitae (CVs) for different sectors

âœ”ï¸ Exploring opportunities in industry and academia

âœ”ï¸ Fundamentals of starting your own company

The program utilizes a three-pronged approach

âœ”ï¸ Online Meetings: Bi-weekly sessions focusing on personal skills (5 sessions) and professional development skills (15 sessions) with insights from both industry and academic professionals.

âœ”ï¸ Local Meetings: Planned twice a year (once per semester) for in-person brainstorming and discussions on challenges and opportunities within the scientific field, related to the online session topics.

âœ”ï¸ Participation in Scientific and Professional Development Events

âœ… Annual Symposium: Opportunities to present work such as literature reviews, qualitative studies, research protocols/results, and outreach activity outcomes as oral or posters presentations.

âœ… Workshop/Webinar: A two-day workshop and webinar featuring industry professionals discussing job opportunities and internship possibilities, including position overviews, desirable profiles, application processes, and interview tips.

âœ… Outreach Activities: Engaging with the community in schools, airports, hospitals, clinics, universities, and local scientific events through stands and group discussions to promote science and opportunities for girls across all scientific disciplines. These 8-hour events will be aligned with institutions and will involve the distribution of informational booklets.

Evaluation - Activities Designed for Each Mentee

âœ”ï¸ Structured pre- and post-program surveys.

âœ”ï¸ Semi-structured pre- and post-program self-evaluations.

âœ”ï¸ Publication of scientific papers (literature reviews or qualitative studies) as a leading researcher.

âœ”ï¸ Recorded 10-minute research project presentations before and after receiving feedback.

âœ”ï¸ Development of both academic and general CVs.

âœ”ï¸ Initiating an online professional presence.

âœ”ï¸ Technical production of a scientific dissemination booklet on a chosen topic.

âœ”ï¸ Book summaries on a personal â€œGood Readsâ€ platform.

âœ”ï¸ Self-evaluation group discussions and reports on outreach activities.

âœ”ï¸ Assessment of attendance and engagement throughout the program.

References for the Book Club

âœ”ï¸ Lean In

âœ”ï¸ Start With Why

âœ”ï¸ The Bullet Journal

âœ”ï¸ The 80/20 Principle

âœ”ï¸ Thinking, Fast and Slow

âœ”ï¸ The Confidence Code

âœ”ï¸ Leaders Eat Last

Communication Channels

âœ”ï¸ WhatsApp community (sorry for more one WhatsApp group!ğŸ˜)

âœ”ï¸ Google Scholar

âœ”ï¸ Emails

âœ”ï¸ Slack

Platforms Used

âœ”ï¸ Meetings and online events: Microsoft Teams

âœ”ï¸ Activity management: Notion

âœ”ï¸ Material exchange: Google Scholar

HOW CAN I BECOME A MENTEE?

Registration and selection will (possibly) take place from July 15th to 31st, and further information will be released at a later date. There will be 10 vacancies for Brazil and 10 vacancies for South Africa.

CONTACT

If you have any ideas, questions or are interested in joining IGNITE as a sponsor, mentor or mentee, please email emilyncosta@gmail.com.
